Award.AwardTitle: Isotopic Methods for Sourcing Shell Beads in California

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
With support from the National Science Foundation, Drs. Jelmer Eerkens and Howard Spero will build on previous research to develop a robust method for tracing the geographic origin of ancient shell beads in Central California. The approach is based on stable isotope signatures preserved in the shells used to make beads. There is significant variation along the California Coast in seasonal water temperature, salinity, and upwelling of cold and nutrient-rich seawater. Together, these effects impart distinctive isotopic signatures to shells growing along different sections of the coast. When a shell is collected on the coast, turned into a bead, and traded inland, it retains the signature of where it originally grew in the calcium carbonate structure of its shell. When archaeologists recover shell artifacts far away from the coast, they can work backwards, from the artifact and through the isotopic signature, to determine where the shell originally grew.

Archaeologists use these types of techniques to trace the movement of raw materials across the landscape and this allows them to reconstruct ancient trading and interaction networks. These trading networks, by extension, allow evaluation of how people adapted to their ever-changing social and natural environments. As new technologies were innovated and spread, demand for raw materials to support them also increased, and reliable access to raw materials that were not locally available would have been important. Archaeologists can trace the history and development of different technologies by examining where raw materials were procured, the style of artifacts produced, and how the two co-evolved over time. Although the specific case study to be examined here addresses ancient trade and exchange of marine shell artifacts in Central California, the approach can be applied to shell artifacts almost anywhere in the world.

In California, indigenous peoples commonly made beads out of the purple olive shell, Olivella biplicata. At the time of contact, in the late 1700s, these shell beads were used in a manner akin to currency and they are ubiquitous in archaeological sites. An exact tally is not available, but over the last 100 years archaeologists have recovered well over a million Olivella beads from sites in Central California. Even the earliest sites in California, dating to over 10,000 years ago, have beads made out of Olivella biplicata. Why Native Californians selected this particular species is not known, but is something the proposed research may be able to address.

This project will support one part-time post-doctoral researcher and one to two UC Davis undergraduate students, who will be trained in geochemical and archaeometric analysis. The data and resulting analysis will be shared with the Central California community through outreach efforts at UC Davis, including public displays at the UCD Anthropology Museum, programs with school children at Bodega Bay Marine Laboratory, and presentations at professional conferences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project sought to develop an archaeometric technique for determining the geographic source of Olivella shell beads. Our approach focused on stable isotope signatures of Oxygen, Carbon, and Strontium in shell beads, that could link shells to particular locations on the Pacific Coast where the snails that produce the shells lived. Based on pilot research and water temperature and salinity modeling, we believed there was an isotopic gradient in shells in stable isotope signatures from south to north along the coast, and from open oceanic to brackish waters. Our research under this grant supported the initial findings of the pilot study, and allowed us to more finely characterize source regions of shell beads.

                In terms of Intellectual Merit, the project was significant for several reasons. First, ethnographic information indicates that Olivella beads were widely used as a form of currency in pre-contact California, and were widely traded across Western North America. One goal, then, was to explore how these trading systems evolved from ancient to ethnographic times. Our research included analysis of Olivella beads found from the coast of California all the way into Central Nevada. From this, we were able to deduce several ancient trading distribution networks, and were able to document how those changed over millennia. Second, archaeological information shows that the shape, size, and manufacturing technique of Olivella beads changed significantly over time. Archaeologists often use these to date sites in the absence of other chronological information. A second goal of the project was to link this morphological variation to geochemical isotopic signatures, and hence, to see if certain bead shapes were produced in certain geographic bead production “centers.” Our research was partially successful here in that we were able to identify bead-specific isotopic signature for some bead types, but not all. This suggests that some bead forms were only produced at specific production centers, while others were more widely produced across the Pacific Coast. This result will help future archaeologists who use bead morphology as a way to date sites to also identify their trading networks. Third, we collected modern water and shell samples, over several years and from several geographic locations. We were especially fortunate in that the last year (2016-2017) was an El Nino year, which allowed us to evaluate how this environmental phenomenon affects shell isotopes. These modern water samples provide important baseline data sets for future researchers wanting to investigate water conditions or other factors associated with oceanic waters. Fourth, we generated a large number of radiocarbon dates for both unmodified archaeological Olivella shells along the coast, and ancient Olivella beads. The dates on unmodified shells allow us to evaluate how sea surface temperature changed over thousands of years along the California Coast, and moreover, how season-to-season variation in temperature also changed (i.e., not just average sea surface temperature as many previous studies have documented, but we can also document changes in the range of intra-annual temperatures over the millennia). The dates on beads allow us to provide finer chronological control for important pre-contact sites, a great value to the archaeological community.

                In terms of Broader Impacts, the project achieved several goals. First, we created a display based on our findings in the UC Davis Museum of Anthropology. This exhibit is open and free to the public for anyone visiting the university campus. Second, we presented some of the findings of the research to the public at two different “Picnic Day” events at UC Davis, through visual displays and “Talk to the Scientist” booths. These events are open to the public and draw tens of thousands of visitors from the region. Third, at least 5 undergraduates from the social sciences participated in the project and were exposed to laboratory-based scientific practices. Such experiences are rare in the social sciences, and thus, this project significantly enriched their education, showing the scientific method in action. One of these undergraduates also participated in the data analysis and writing phases, and had the opportunity to present some of the research at two different conferences (as first author), and appears as a co-author on a publication in a peer-reviewed journal. Fourth, one graduate student is currently finishing a PhD dissertation based on data generated in the project, and another professional served as a post-doc on the project, helping to develop her professional career.
